content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 6 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “A of t, in automobiles.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. A of t is 0. Column 2. t is 15. A of t is 30. Column 3. t is 45. A of t is 190. Column 4. t is 70. A of t is 250. Column 5. t is 90. A of t is 405. Column 6. t is 100. A of t is 600."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="9em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>15</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>45</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>70</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>90</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>100</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(automobiles)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>30</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>190</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>250</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>405</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>600</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> Prior to a sporting event, the number of automobiles that have entered a stadium parking lot is modeled by the differentiable function <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of minutes since the parking lot opened. Values of <math alttext="A of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for selected values of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. According to the model, what is the average rate at which automobiles enter the parking lot, in automobiles per minute, over the time interval <math alttext="45 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 90"><mstyle><mrow><mn>45</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes?

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 6 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “A of t, in automobiles.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. A of t is 0. Column 2. t is 15. A of t is 30. Column 3. t is 45. A of t is 190. Column 4. t is 70. A of t is 250. Column 5. t is 90. A of t is 405. Column 6. t is 100. A of t is 600."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="9em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>15</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>45</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>70</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>90</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>100</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(automobiles)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>30</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>190</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>250</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>405</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>600</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> Prior to a sporting event, the number of automobiles that have entered a stadium parking lot is modeled by the differentiable function <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of minutes since the parking lot opened. Values of <math alttext="A of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for selected values of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. According to the model, what is the average rate at which automobiles enter the parking lot, in automobiles per minute, over the time interval <math alttext="45 is less than or equal to t, which is less than or equal to 90"><mstyle><mrow><mn>45</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes?

Write <math alttext="A prime of 95"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>95</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> as the limit of a difference quotient. Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="A prime of 95"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>95</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

What is the shortest time interval during which it is guaranteed that <math alttext="A of t, equals 400"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for some time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval? Justify your answer.

For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 45"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>45</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the function <math alttext="f"><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></math> defined by <math alttext="f of t equals, the fraction 2 over 27, end fraction, times t squared, plus the fraction 8 over 9, end fraction, times t"><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>27</mn></mrow></mfrac><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>t</mi></mrow></math> models the number of automobiles that have entered the parking lot, where <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of minutes since the parking lot opened. Find <math alttext="f prime of 10"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the rate at which automobiles enter the parking lot, in automobiles per minute, at time <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes.

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 3.E: Provide reasons or rationales for solutions and conclusions.
